Author: alec
Content: No, it couldn't - your rewording loses the critical "reportedly" that lets the reader know that this is a rumor, not fact.  I am not a reporter, and don't know the threshold for libel, but for a rumor you definitely want to write that, just like newspapers always use "the alledged criminal" before the trial is over.

Author: edw519
Content:
I hope the code I'm writing today will be bringing someone value 20 years from now.

(5 years ago, while working on a local company's packaged software, I came across a program that I had written for the software vendor 10 years earlier. Weird.)

Somehow, "2008 Color Trends" seems pretty unimportant in the grand scheme of things.

Author: ALee
Content:
Spoke with a friend who helped Brad Feld start Techstars. Although I still see YC as the best of all these a seed funds, he said TS has three differences:

1) Not PG rigid. He characterized PG as treating investors like the devil in the early stage. They think otherwise, bringing more mentors from the investment arena.\n2) laid back location- Although silicon valley is a great place, they value creative environment over competitive atmosphere. Boulder is the place for that according to TS.\n3) Hands-on mentors- YC brings them in and they talk, but TS brings them in and then you still have access later on. He asked, how many times have YC founders talked to Joe Kraus after he came and talked.

Both PG and Brad Feld (Techstars creator) have their own blogs and their college groupies (and then some), but I think it depends on the experience you want.

Author: thomasfl
Content: Great read, even if it's really no such thing as "web2.0 design".

Author: davidw
Content:
Even if you favor that sort of outcome, there are different ways of accomplishing it. The best ways would be the most direct and the most transparent, or else you end up with things like the farm subsidies, where, in the popular image, it's the small farmers producing local products that everyone wants to help, but the big agribusinesses that reap the benefits.

Off the top of my head, an alternate method of promoting small local shops would be tax discounts for family owned stores with only one location. This would help them compete without absurd, ham-handed intervention like the government dictating prices and opening hours.
